title: German submarine U-457
text:
German submarine "U-457" was a <a href="German%20Type%20VII%20submarine%23Type%20VIIC">Type VIIC</a> <a href="U-boat">U-boat</a> of <a href="Nazi%20Germany">Nazi Germany</a>'s "<a href="Kriegsmarine">Kriegsmarine</a>" during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>.
She carried out three patrols, on which she sank two ships and damaged one more.
She was sunk northeast of the <a href="North%20Cape%2C%20Norway">North Cape</a> by a British warship on 16 September 1942.
Design.
<a href="German%20Type%20VII%20submarine%23Type%20VIIC">German Type VIIC submarines</a> were preceded by the shorter <a href="German%20Type%20VII%20submarine%23Type%20VIIB">Type VIIB submarines</a>. "U-457" had a displacement of when at the surface and while submerged. She had a total length of , a <a href="pressure%20hull">pressure hull</a> length of , a <a href="beam%20%28nautical%29">beam</a> of , a height of , and a <a href="draught%20%28ship%29">draught</a> of . The submarine was powered by two <a href="Germaniawerft">Germaniawerft</a> F46 four-stroke, six-cylinder <a href="supercharged">supercharged</a> <a href="diesel%20engine">diesel engine</a>s producing a total of for use while surfaced, two <a href="Siemens-Schuckert">Siemens-Schuckert</a> GU 343/38–8 <a href="Motor%E2%80%93generator">double-acting electric motors</a> producing a total of for use while submerged. She had two shafts and two <a href="propeller">propeller</a>s. The boat was capable of operating at depths of up to .
The submarine had a maximum surface speed of and a maximum submerged speed of . When submerged, the boat could operate for at ; when surfaced, she could travel at . "U-457" was fitted with five <a href="torpedo%20tube">torpedo tube</a>s (four fitted at the bow and one at the stern), fourteen <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a>es, one <a href="8.8%20cm%20SK%20C/35%20naval%20gun">SK C/35 naval gun</a>, 220 rounds, and a <a href="2%20cm%20FlaK%2030">C/30</a> anti-aircraft gun. The boat had a <a href="Ship%27s%20company">complement</a> of between forty-four and sixty.
Service history.
The submarine was <a href="Keel%20laying">laid down</a> on 26 October 1940 in the <a href="Deutsche%20Werke">Deutsche Werke</a>, <a href="Kiel">Kiel</a> as yard number 288, <a href="Ceremonial%20ship%20launching">launched</a> on 4 October 1941 and <a href="Ship%20commissioning">commissioned</a> on 5 November under the command of "<a href="Korvettenkapit%C3%A4n">Korvettenkapitän</a>" Karl Brandenburg.
She served with the <a href="6th%20U-boat%20Flotilla">6th U-boat Flotilla</a> from 5 November 1941 for training and the <a href="11th%20U-boat%20Flotilla">11th flotilla</a> from 1 July 1942 for operations.
First patrol.
"U-457"s first patrol was preceded by two short journeys from Kiel to <a href="Trondheim">Trondheim</a> in Norway. The patrol itself commenced with her departure from Trondheim on 28 June 1942.
She sank the "Christopher Newport" east of <a href="Bear%20Island%20%28Norway%29">Bear Island</a> on 4 July. The ship, from the ill-fated <a href="convoy%20PQ%2017">convoy PQ 17</a>, had already been hit by an aerial <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a> in the <a href="Barents%20Sea">Barents Sea</a>. A 'coup de grace' torpedo from the British submarine "P-614" failed to sink the ship; but one from "U-457" succeeded.
The boat then went on to sink the <a href="RFA%20Aldersdale%20%28X34%29">RFA "Aldersdale"</a> on 7 July 1942; after the merchantman, also a member of PQ 17, had been bombed. "U-457" came across the abandoned tanker and after firing 75 rounds from her <a href="deck%20gun">deck gun</a>, finished the wreck off with a single torpedo.
Second patrol.
Her second foray was relatively uneventful - starting in <a href="Narvik">Narvik</a> on 8 August 1942 and finishing in Trondheim on 7 September.
Third patrol and loss.
The submarine damaged the <a href="MV%20Atheltemplar">"Atheltemplar"</a> of the <a href="Convoy%20PQ%2018">Convoy PQ 18</a> on 14 September 1942 south of <a href="Spitsbergen">Spitsbergen</a> (Svalbard). "U-457" was sunk on the 16th by <a href="depth%20charge">depth charge</a>s from the British destroyer .
Forty-five men died in "U-457"; there were no survivors.
